info.game_comments:
1997-B Teen Tournament semifinal game 1.
From DAR Constitution Hall in Washington, D.C.

(1, 1).clue: Can you hear me?  This rock opera by The Who was a big hit at the Kennedy Center in 1994

(2, 1).clue: George Custer's men are buried in a cemetery in the national monument named for this river

(3, 1).clue: Trainers shout, "Tail Up!" when they want these performers to follow each other trunk to tail

(4, 1).clue: Radio abbreviation that precedes the name of rap figures Quik, Pooh & Jazzy Jeff

(5, 1).clue: On March 2, 1977 he made his first "Tonight Show" appearance; on May 25, 1992 he took over as host

(1, 2).clue: In 1995 Luigi Bonino starred in a ballet about this "Little Tramp" of silent films

(2, 2).clue: Scotts Bluff National Monument lies in western Nebraska on this pioneer trail

(3, 2).clue: It's the familiar term for a circus' largest tent, where the main show appears

(4, 2).clue: Robin Quivers is the radio consort of this self-proclaimed  "King of All Media"

(5, 2).clue: (Hi, I'm Bob Eubanks.)  Tea Leoni ran into this "X-Files" star at the Golden Globes & soon they were newlyweds

(1, 3).clue: This president's 1972 visit to China inspired an opera that played at the Kennedy Center in 1988

(2, 3).clue: Seminole Indian leader Osceola is buried at this fort where the Civil War began

(3, 3).clue: Pink is the most popular color of this fluffy confection made from spun sugar

(4, 3).clue: Call letters east of the Mississippi generally start with W; in the west, most start with this

(5, 3).clue: People Magazine called his 1997 solo album "Destination Anywhere", "Tres Bon"

(6, 3).clue: Peeling onions,watching Mel Gibson's film "Forever Young",missing Final Jeopardy!

(1, 4).clue: Every December, the Kennedy Center invites the public to a free sing-along of this composer's "Messiah"

(2, 4).clue: This Wyoming monument contains an 865-foot-high fluted column of igneous rock

(3, 4).clue: Antoinette Concello's triple somersault helped make her the "Queen of" this "flying" apparatus

(4, 4).clue: Detroit-born broadcaster who created "American Top 40" & now has his own weekly "Countdown"

(5, 4).clue: In a 1997 issue of "George", he said his cousins Michael & Joseph were "poster boys for bad behavior"

(1, 5).clue: A 1994 festival honoring this country featured the Tjapukai Aboriginal Dance Company

(2, 5).clue: Castillo de San Marcos in this Florida city is the oldest masonry fort in the continental U.S.

(3, 5).clue: This steam whistle organ draws crowds to circus parades because it can be heard from miles away:[audio clue]

(4, 5).clue: The AAA format, featuring artists like the Cranberries & Tom Petty, stands for adult album this

(5, 5).clue: Her 1988 major label debut album was "Y Kant Tori Read"

(1, 1).clue: The one word quothed by Edgar Allan Poe's raven

(2, 1).clue: You can't make a genuine tempera painting without breaking these

(3, 1).clue: On Sept. 5, 1781, 24 of this country's ships engaged British ships in Cheaspeake Bay & turned them back

(4, 1).clue: Chuck Taylor, from whom Converse named a line of these shoes, was a basketball star of the 1910s

(5, 1).clue: It's the go-ahead in a kid's game & for a car at an intersection

(1, 2).clue: It follows "Poems are made by fools like me..."
(1, 2).correct response: "But only God can make a tree"

(2, 2).clue: Surrealists used odd juxtapositions in this form whose name is French for "gluing"

(3, 2).clue: During the war, this first signer of the Declaration of Independence commanded the Mass. Militia

(4, 2).clue: The L.A. Dodgers & the U. of Louisville basketball team pioneered this gesture in the late '70s

(5, 2).clue: A baker who never uses packaged mixes always "starts from" here

(1, 3).clue: In preparing to write this poem, Longfellow used "An historical and statistical account of Nova Scotia"

(2, 3).clue: Edward Steichen led the movement to recognize as art these images, whose name means "drawn with light"

(3, 3).clue: In it, Thomas Paine wrote, "The cause of America is in a great measure the cause of all mankind"

(4, 3).clue: Coastal waters beyond national jurisdiction, or the tops of some sopranos' ranges

(5, 3).clue: It's a ship at home in the Arctic, or a remark that starts a conversation

(1, 4).clue: In a poem titled for the date when Germany invaded Poland, W.H. Auden called this "A low dishonest decade"

(2, 4).clue: 17th century Flemish master known for painting women like the one seen here:

(3, 4).clue: The Battle of Long Island was fought in what is now this New York City borough

(4, 4).clue: The HD in the new digital format HDTV stands for this

(5, 4).clue: It begins a football game or a special event like a political campaign

(1, 5).clue: Observing pilgrims traveling to the shrine of Thomas Becket inspired him to write his greatest work

(2, 5).clue: In 1920 this impressionist, known for his water lilies, painted another plant, "Wisteria"

(3, 5).clue: The British ferried 2,200 troops across this river to battle the Americans at Bunker Hill

(4, 5).clue: Acolytes, a subdeacon & a choir take part in this Catholic service

(5, 5).clue: In a business project, it's the level investors try to "get in on"
(5, 5).correct response: the ground floor (or the ground level)

(0, 0).clue: Word completing the line "Nor shall any person be subject for the same offense to be twice put in" this
